expanded_description: Matrices are rectangular arrays of numbers that organize and process information in ways that ordinary algebra cannot. They are the backbone of computer graphics, data science, economics, physics, and engineering. Before matrices can do anything powerful — solving systems of equations, encoding messages, rotating shapes — you need to be comfortable with the basic operations: adding, subtracting, and scaling them. This section builds that foundation from the ground up.

core_concept.principle: A matrix is a rectangular array of numbers arranged in rows and columns. Matrix operations — addition, subtraction, and scalar multiplication — work element by element, operating on corresponding entries. Two matrices can only be added or subtracted if they have exactly the same dimensions.
core_concept.explanation: Think of a matrix as a spreadsheet: rows going across, columns going down, and each cell holding a number. When you add two spreadsheets together, you add the number in each cell of the first spreadsheet to the number in the same cell of the second spreadsheet. That is exactly how matrix addition works — position by position, entry by entry. This is called element-wise operation, and it is the defining logic of all three operations in this section. Scalar multiplication is even simpler: multiply every single entry in the matrix by the same number (the scalar). These operations are the vocabulary you need before matrix multiplication, inverses, and all the powerful applications ahead.

sections.section_title: What Is a Matrix? — Vocabulary and Notation
sections.introduction: Before we can do any operations, we need precise language for talking about matrices. This vocabulary appears on every assessment in this unit — know it cold. Many students skip this section thinking it is just definitions, then lose points on notation errors for the rest of the unit.

key_concept.definition: A matrix is a rectangular array of numbers enclosed in brackets. The numbers inside are called entries or elements. A matrix is described by its dimensions: $m \times n$ (read $m$ by $n$), where $m$ is the number of rows and $n$ is the number of columns. A matrix named $A$ with entry in row $i$ and column $j$ is written $a_{ij}$ (lowercase letter with subscript).
key_concept.context: Rows run horizontally (left to right). Columns run vertically (up to down). When stating dimensions, ALWAYS say rows first, then columns — $m \times n$ means $m$ rows and $n$ columns. This order is universal and must be memorized. A matrix is usually named with a capital letter ($A$, $B$, $C$) and individual entries with the corresponding lowercase letter and subscripts ($a_{11}$, $a_{12}$, etc.). The subscript $a_{ij}$ is read 'a sub i j' — $i$ is the row number, $j$ is the column number.

classifications.value: Always identify dimension before performing any operation — it determines what is and is not allowed
characteristics: Dimension = (number of rows) $\times$ (number of columns), written $m \times n$
Rows are horizontal — count them going down
Columns are vertical — count them going across
A $2 \times 3$ matrix has 2 rows and 3 columns (6 total entries)
A $3 \times 2$ matrix has 3 rows and 2 columns (also 6 entries — but a different shape)
A $2 \times 3$ and a $3 \times 2$ are NOT the same — dimension order matters
A square matrix has equal rows and columns: $n \times n$
A $1 \times n$ matrix (one row) is called a row vector; an $m \times 1$ matrix (one column) is a column vector
classifications.behavior: To find dimensions: count the horizontal strips (rows) — that is $m$. Count the vertical strips (columns) — that is $n$. Write $m \times n$. Do this before any calculation. The most common dimension error is reversing rows and columns. Memory aid: RC Cola — Rows Come first, then Columns. A reliable check: does the matrix look wider (more columns than rows) or taller (more rows than columns)?

examples.explanation: Matrix $A$ = <<3,7,-1|0,4,5>>. Count horizontal strips: 2 rows. Count vertical strips: 3 columns. Dimension: $2 \times 3$. The matrix looks wide — more columns than rows. There are $2 \times 3 = 6$ total entries.

Matrix $B$ = <<1,-2|3,0>>. 2 rows, 2 columns. Dimension: $2 \times 2$. This is a square matrix — equal rows and columns. Square matrices are special: only square matrices can have determinants and inverses (Sections 14.3 and 14.5).

Matrix $C$ = <<4|-1|7>>. 3 rows, 1 column. Dimension: $3 \times 1$. This is a column vector — a tall, single-column matrix. Column vectors are the output of matrix-vector multiplication in Section 14.4.
Matrix $D$ = <<2,-5,8,1>>. 1 row, 4 columns. Dimension: $1 \times 4$. This is a row vector — a single-row matrix.

classifications.value: Read and write entry notation fluently — it appears in every matrix formula in this unit
characteristics: $a_{ij}$ is the entry in row $i$, column $j$ of matrix $A$
The row index $i$ is always listed first — then the column index $j$
$a_{11}$ is always the top-left entry (row 1, column 1)
$a_{12}$ is row 1, column 2 — one step right from $a_{11}$
$a_{21}$ is row 2, column 1 — one step down from $a_{11}$
Think of it as a map coordinate: first go to the right row, then move to the right column
classifications.behavior: When asked for $a_{ij}$, move to row $i$ first (count down from the top), then column $j$ (count right from the left). The subscript reads like an address: $a_{23}$ means row 2, column 3 — go to the second row, then find the third entry in it. Note: $a_{23}$ and $a_{32}$ are completely different entries.

examples.explanation: Matrix $A$ = <<5,-2,8|1,0,-4|3,7,6>>. Find $a_{11}$: row 1, column 1 = 5. Find $a_{23}$: row 2, column 3 = -4. Find $a_{32}$: row 3, column 2 = 7. Find $a_{13}$: row 1, column 3 = 8. Note that $a_{23} = -4$ but $a_{32} = 7$ — the order of subscripts matters completely.

examples.process: Using Equality to Solve for Unknowns
examples.explanation: If <<x+1,4|3,y-2>> = <<7,4|3,5>>, then matching entry by entry: position (1,1): $x + 1 = 7$ so $x = 6$. Position (2,2): $y - 2 = 5$ so $y = 7$. Setting matrices equal creates one equation per entry.

classifications.value: Recognize these on sight — they appear throughout Unit 14
characteristics: Square matrix: $n \times n$ — same number of rows and columns; required for determinants and inverses
Row matrix (row vector): $1 \times n$ — a single row
Column matrix (column vector): $m \times 1$ — a single column
Zero matrix $O$: every entry is 0; the additive identity (like 0 for numbers)
Equal matrices: same dimensions AND every corresponding entry is equal
A $2 \times 3$ and a $3 \times 2$ matrix are NEVER equal — dimensions must match first
classifications.behavior: When two matrices are set equal to each other, every corresponding entry must be equal — this creates a system of equations, one per entry. This technique is used throughout the unit to find unknown values. Always check dimensions first before testing entry equality.

examples.explanation: Are <<2,5|-1,3>> and <<2,5|-1,3>> equal? Same dimensions ($2 \times 2$) and all corresponding entries match: yes, they are equal matrices.

The $2 \times 2$ zero matrix is <<0,0|0,0>>. Adding it to any $2 \times 2$ matrix $A$ gives $A + O = A$ — just like adding 0 to a number. Every dimension has its own zero matrix: <<0,0,0|0,0,0>> is the $2 \times 3$ zero matrix.

sections.introduction: Matrix addition is the most intuitive matrix operation — if you can add numbers, you can add matrices. The key rule is simple but absolute: you can only add two matrices if they have exactly the same dimensions. Then you add entry by entry, position by position.

key_concept.definition: To add two matrices $A$ and $B$ of the same dimension, add their corresponding entries. The entry at position $(i, j)$ of the result $A + B$ equals $a_{ij} + b_{ij}$. The result has the same dimensions as $A$ and $B$.
key_concept.context: Matrix addition is commutative ($A + B = B + A$) and associative ($(A + B) + C = A + (B + C)$) — the same properties as regular number addition. These make sense because each position is just doing regular addition. The zero matrix $O$ is the additive identity: $A + O = A$.

classifications.value: Add entry by entry in the same position; only possible when dimensions match exactly
characteristics: Requirement: both matrices must have identical dimensions
Method: add the entry at position $(i, j)$ in $A$ to the entry at position $(i, j)$ in $B$
Result: a new matrix with the same dimensions as the originals
Cannot add matrices of different dimensions — this is undefined
Commutative: $A + B = B + A$
Associative: $(A + B) + C = A + (B + C)$
Adding the zero matrix $O$ leaves a matrix unchanged: $A + O = A$
classifications.behavior: Step 1: Check dimensions — both matrices must be the same size. If they are not, stop and write undefined. Step 2: Create a result matrix of the same size. Step 3: Fill in each entry by adding the two corresponding entries. Work row by row, left to right. Step 4: Write the completed result matrix.

examples.explanation: Can we add <<2,3|1,4>> (which is $2 \times 2$) and <<5,0,-1|2,3,4>> (which is $2 \times 3$)? No — the first has 2 columns and the second has 3. There is no matching entry for column 3 of the second matrix. This addition is undefined. Always check dimensions first.

sections.introduction: Matrix subtraction follows the exact same logic as matrix addition — entry by entry — with a minus sign instead of a plus. The same dimension requirement applies, and the same systematic approach works. The one extra caution: order matters in subtraction, and negative entries create double negatives to watch for.

key_concept.definition: To subtract matrix $B$ from matrix $A$ (both the same dimension), subtract corresponding entries: the entry at position $(i, j)$ of $A - B$ is $a_{ij} - b_{ij}$. The result has the same dimensions.
key_concept.context: Matrix subtraction is NOT commutative: $A - B \neq B - A$ in general — just like regular subtraction $5 - 3 \neq 3 - 5$. Keep track of which matrix comes first. An alternative framing: $A - B = A + (-B)$, where $-B$ is the matrix with all entries negated. Flip every sign in $B$, then add.

classifications.type: Matrix Subtraction — Entry by Entry with Order Awareness
classifications.value: Same rule as addition but with subtraction; ORDER MATTERS since $A - B \neq B - A$
characteristics: Requirement: both matrices must have identical dimensions
Method: subtract the $(i,j)$ entry of $B$ FROM the $(i,j)$ entry of $A$
Result: a new matrix with the same dimensions
NOT commutative: $A - B \neq B - A$
Alternative: negate all entries of $B$ to get $-B$, then add: $A - B = A + (-B)$
Subtracting the zero matrix leaves $A$ unchanged: $A - O = A$
classifications.behavior: For each position $(i,j)$: write the entry from $A$ first, then subtract the entry from $B$ in the same position. The most common error is computing $b_{ij} - a_{ij}$ (backward). When $b_{ij}$ is negative, the subtraction becomes addition — always rewrite $a_{ij} - (-k)$ as $a_{ij} + k$ explicitly to avoid double-negative errors.

examples.process: Subtracting with Negative Entries — Watch Double Negatives
examples.explanation: <<5,-2|0,-8>> - <<-3,4|-1,-5>>. Position (1,1): $5-(-3) = 5+3 = 8$. Position (1,2): $-2-4 = -6$. Position (2,1): $0-(-1) = 0+1 = 1$. Position (2,2): $-8-(-5) = -8+5 = -3$. Result: <<8,-6|1,-3>>. Always rewrite subtracting a negative as adding a positive.

examples.process: Why Order Matters — $A - B$ vs $B - A$
examples.explanation: Let $A$ = <<6,1|-2,4>> and $B$ = <<3,5|0,-1>>. Then $A - B$ = <<3,-4|-2,5>> and $B - A$ = <<-3,4|2,-5>>. Every entry has the opposite sign. $A - B$ and $B - A$ always produce negatives of each other: $B - A = -(A - B)$.

sections.introduction: A scalar is just a regular number (not a matrix). Scalar multiplication means multiplying an entire matrix by a single number. The rule is the simplest in this section: multiply every single entry in the matrix by that number. No dimension check required — just scale everything uniformly.

key_concept.definition: To multiply a matrix $A$ by a scalar $k$, multiply every entry of $A$ by $k$. The result $kA$ has the same dimensions as $A$, and every entry $a_{ij}$ becomes $k \cdot a_{ij}$.
key_concept.context: Scalar multiplication distributes over matrix addition: $k(A + B) = kA + kB$. It also works across scalars: $(k \cdot m)A = k(mA)$. Scalar $1$ leaves a matrix unchanged. Scalar $0$ produces the zero matrix. Scalar $-1$ negates every entry, producing $-A$ (the additive inverse). These properties are the same as distributing a constant in regular algebra.

classifications.value: The simplest matrix operation — no dimension check needed, just multiply every entry by the scalar
characteristics: Multiply EVERY entry in the matrix by the scalar $k$ — no exceptions
The result has the same dimensions as the original matrix
Works on any matrix regardless of size
Distributes over addition: $k(A + B) = kA + kB$
Scalar 1 is the multiplicative identity: $1 \cdot A = A$
Scalar 0 produces the zero matrix: $0 \cdot A = O$
Scalar $-1$ negates every entry: $-1 \cdot A = -A$
classifications.behavior: Multiply the scalar by the first entry, write it down, move to the next entry, multiply again — continue until every entry is done. Work row by row. With a negative scalar, every positive entry becomes negative and vice versa. The most common mistake: only multiplying some entries. The scalar touches EVERY entry in EVERY row and EVERY column.

examples.explanation: $-2 \times$ <<4,-3|-1,7>>. Multiply each entry by $-2$: (1,1): $-2 \times 4 = -8$. (1,2): $-2 \times (-3) = +6$. (2,1): $-2 \times (-1) = +2$. (2,2): $-2 \times 7 = -14$. Result: <<-8,6|2,-14>>. A negative scalar flips the sign of every entry.

sections.section_title: Combining Operations — Expressions with Multiple Matrix Operations
sections.introduction: Real problems rarely ask for just one operation in isolation. More often you will need to add and scale matrices in the same expression — just like algebraic expressions that combine multiple operations. The order of operations from regular algebra applies directly: scalar multiplications first, then additions and subtractions.

key_concept.definition: Matrix expressions follow the same order of operations as regular algebra: perform scalar multiplications first, then additions and subtractions. For an expression like $2A + 3B$: compute $2A$ first, compute $3B$ first, then add the results.
key_concept.context: The distributive property works here: $k(A + B) = kA + kB$. Factoring also works: if every entry in a matrix shares a common factor, you can pull it out as a scalar. These are the same moves from regular algebra — they apply identically to matrices because all operations are entry-wise.

categories.description: Scalar multiplication first, then addition or subtraction. Compute each scaled matrix separately, then combine entry by entry.
categories.detailed_mechanism: Step 1: Identify all scalar multiplications in the expression. Step 2: Compute each scalar-matrix product. Step 3: Check that all resulting matrices have the same dimensions. Step 4: Add or subtract the resulting matrices entry by entry. Step 5: Write the final result. Never try to merge steps — write out each intermediate matrix fully before combining.

categories.description: Matrix equations can be solved for an unknown matrix using the same algebraic moves as regular equations — isolate the unknown by adding, subtracting, or scalar-multiplying both sides.
categories.detailed_mechanism: If $A + X = B$, then $X = B - A$. If $2X = A$, then $X = \frac{1}{2}A$. If $3X - B = C$, then $3X = C + B$, so $X = \frac{1}{3}(C + B)$. Every algebraic move works — the only difference is that each operation applies entry by entry.

examples.explanation: Given $A$ = <<10,-6|4,8>>, find $X$. Multiply both sides by $\frac{1}{2}$: $X = \frac{1}{2}A$. Divide every entry by 2. Result: $X$ = <<5,-3|2,4>>.

sections.section_title: Real-World Context — Why Matrix Operations Matter
sections.introduction: Matrix operations are not just abstract arithmetic — they model real situations where data is organized in grids. Adding, subtracting, and scaling matrices becomes a natural way to update inventories, compare datasets, calculate totals, and track changes across two categories simultaneously.

key_concept.definition: Matrices are used to organize data with two categories simultaneously — for example, multiple products across multiple stores, or multiple subjects across multiple students. Matrix addition combines datasets, subtraction shows change, and scalar multiplication scales an entire dataset uniformly.
key_concept.context: Whenever data has two dimensions — rows representing one category (stores, students, days) and columns representing another (products, subjects, activities) — a matrix is the natural container. Operations on these matrices have direct, interpretable real-world meaning. This previews Section 14.10 where these ideas are developed fully.

categories.description: Matrices naturally represent inventory data — rows might be product types and columns might be sizes or colors. Adding matrices combines inventories; subtracting shows sales or losses; scalar multiplication adjusts prices or quantities uniformly.
categories.detailed_mechanism: If matrix $A$ represents a store's inventory at the start of the week and matrix $B$ represents items sold, then $A - B$ gives remaining inventory. If matrix $C$ represents a shipment received, then $A - B + C$ gives the updated inventory. Scalar multiplication scales all quantities — if a store doubles its order, multiply the order matrix by 2.

examples.explanation: Store inventory (rows = shirts and pants; columns = sizes S, M, L). Start of week: $A$ = <<20,35,15|10,25,30>>. Sold this week: $B$ = <<8,12,5|3,10,14>>. Remaining inventory: $A - B$ = <<12,23,10|7,15,16>>. Each entry gives the exact remaining count for that item-size combination.
Store 1: $A$ = <<15,20|8,12>>. Store 2: $B$ = <<10,18|5,9>>. Combined company total: $A + B$ = <<25,38|13,21>>. Adding two store matrices gives the company-wide total at each position.
A restaurant's prices: $P$ = <<8,10,12|5,7,9>> (dollars). If all prices rise 15%, multiply by $1.15$: $1.15P$ = <<9.20,11.50,13.80|5.75,8.05,10.35>>. Every price increases proportionally in one step.

sections.introduction: These worked examples require multiple operations in sequence, solving for unknowns, and connecting calculations to real-world context. They model the depth expected on assessments.

key_concept.definition: Multi-step matrix problems require: identifying dimensions and checking compatibility, performing operations in the correct order, tracking signs carefully with negative entries, and interpreting results in context when a real-world situation is given.
key_concept.context: The most important habit for multi-step problems: write out each intermediate matrix fully before moving to the next step. Trying to do multiple operations simultaneously leads to entry errors that cascade through the rest of the problem.

worked_examples.title: Evaluating $2A - 3B + C$

step_by_step.explanation: All three matrices must have the same dimension for this expression to be defined.
step_by_step.calculation: $A$: $2 \times 2$. $B$: $2 \times 2$. $C$: $2 \times 2$. All match. The result will also be $2 \times 2$.

step_by_step.explanation: Subtract $3B$ from $2A$ entry by entry. Watch the double negatives.
Add $C$ to the result from the previous step, entry by entry.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Always compute scalar multiplications before additions and subtractions. Write out each intermediate matrix fully — do not try to merge steps or errors will compound.

worked_examples.title: Solving a Matrix Equation for an Unknown Matrix
worked_examples.problem: Find matrix $X$ such that $3X - A = B$, where $A$ = <<6,-3|0,9>> and $B$ = <<15,3|-6,12>>.

step_by_step.explanation: Treat this like an algebraic equation. Isolate $X$ using inverse operations.
step_by_step.calculation: $3X - A = B$. Goal: get $X$ alone on one side.

step_by_step.explanation: Add $A$ to both sides to eliminate $-A$ on the left.
Multiply both sides by $\frac{1}{3}$ to isolate $X$.
Substitute back into the original equation to confirm.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Solving a matrix equation uses the same algebraic moves as solving a regular equation — add, subtract, or multiply both sides — but every operation applies entry by entry. Always verify by substituting back into the original equation.

worked_examples.title: Two-Store Inventory Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A company has two stores. Inventory (rows = jackets and jeans; columns = colors black, blue, gray): Store 1: $A$ = <<30,45,20|50,60,35>>. Store 2: $B$ = <<25,30,40|45,55,20>>. (a) Find total combined inventory. (b) A shipment doubles Store 1 inventory. Find the new Store 1 inventory. (c) Store 1 then sells $S$ = <<10,15,8|18,22,12>> units. Find Store 1 inventory after shipment and sales.

step_by_step.explanation: Add the two store matrices to find total inventory at each position.
step_by_step.calculation: $A + B$: Row 1: $30+25=55$, $45+30=75$, $20+40=60$. Row 2: $50+45=95$, $60+55=115$, $35+20=55$. Combined: <<55,75,60|95,115,55>>. The company has 55 black jackets, 75 blue jackets, 60 gray jackets, 95 black jeans, 115 blue jeans, 55 gray jeans.

step_by_step.explanation: Doubling the current inventory means multiplying matrix $A$ by 2.
Start with doubled inventory $2A$, then subtract the sales matrix $S$.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Real-world matrix problems require connecting each operation to its meaning. Addition combines data; subtraction removes items; scalar multiplication scales uniformly. Identify what rows and columns represent before computing to make interpretation straightforward.

sections.section_title: Common Mistakes and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Matrix operations have a small number of specific, repeatable error patterns. These are the mistakes that appear on every assessment — knowing them in advance means you can catch them before they cost you points.

key_concept.definition: The most common errors: attempting operations on matrices with incompatible dimensions, only partially applying scalar multiplication, sign errors with double negatives in subtraction, reversing the order in subtraction ($b_{ij} - a_{ij}$ instead of $a_{ij} - b_{ij}$), and confusing rows with columns when stating dimensions.
key_concept.context: Every error in this list is preventable with one habit: slow down and work systematically, entry by entry, checking dimensions before you start. The operations themselves are not difficult — errors come from rushing.

categories.type: Mistake 1: Adding or Subtracting Matrices of Different Dimensions
categories.description: Matrix addition and subtraction require identical dimensions. There is no way to add a $2 \times 3$ matrix to a $3 \times 2$ matrix — even though both have 6 entries, they do not have matching positions.
categories.detailed_mechanism: The fix: always state the dimensions of both matrices before computing. If they do not match exactly, write undefined and stop. There is no workaround — not even with zeros in extra positions.

examples.explanation: $A$ is $3 \times 2$ and $B$ is $3 \times 3$. Can we compute $A + B$? $A$ has 2 columns, $B$ has 3 — different. Addition is undefined. Write undefined and stop. Do not attempt to align them or pad with zeros.

categories.description: Students often multiply only the first row, only the diagonal, or only a few entries by the scalar — missing one or more. The scalar multiplies EVERY entry with no exceptions.
categories.detailed_mechanism: Work row by row, left to right, and count entries when finished. If the count does not match the matrix dimensions, you missed one. In a $3 \times 3$ matrix that is 9 multiplications. In a $2 \times 4$ that is 8. Count them.

examples.explanation: $3 \times$ <<2,4|1,5>>. WRONG (only first entry): <<6,4|1,5>>. WRONG (only first row): <<6,12|1,5>>. CORRECT (every entry): <<6,12|3,15>>. The scalar touches every cell — no exceptions.

categories.description: When subtracting a matrix that contains negative entries, subtracting a negative produces a sum — not a difference. Students frequently forget the second negative sign.
categories.detailed_mechanism: When $b_{ij}$ is negative: $a_{ij} - (\text{negative number}) = a_{ij} + (\text{positive number})$. Always rewrite explicitly: $a_{ij} - (-k) = a_{ij} + k$ before calculating.

categories.description: In $A - B$, you subtract $B$'s entries FROM $A$'s entries — not the other way around. Reversing gives the negated result and is completely wrong.
categories.detailed_mechanism: Before computing each entry in $A - B$, write the entry from $A$ first, then subtract the entry from $B$. $A - B$ and $B - A$ produce matrices that are negatives of each other — every sign flipped.

examples.explanation: $A$ = <<5,2>> and $B$ = <<3,8>>. $A - B$: $(5-3, 2-8) = (2, -6)$. $B - A$: $(3-5, 8-2) = (-2, 6)$. Every sign is opposite. Read the problem carefully to know which matrix comes first.

categories.type: Mistake 5: Confusing Row and Column Order in Dimensions
categories.description: Students reverse the dimension notation — writing $n \times m$ when the matrix is $m \times n$. Dimensions are ALWAYS rows first, columns second.
categories.detailed_mechanism: A matrix with 3 rows and 4 columns is $3 \times 4$ — never $4 \times 3$. Memory aid: RC Cola — Rows Come first, then Columns. A $3 \times 4$ and a $4 \times 3$ matrix cannot be added, so getting this wrong leads to incorrectly claiming operations are defined when they are not.

examples.explanation: Matrix $A$ has 4 rows and 2 columns: dimension $4 \times 2$ (RC — rows first). Matrix $B$ has 2 rows and 4 columns: dimension $2 \times 4$ (still RC). Can $A + B$ be computed? $A$ is $4 \times 2$, $B$ is $2 \times 4$ — different dimensions, undefined. Without the RC rule someone might say both have 4 and 2 so they match — they do not.

summary: A matrix is an $m \times n$ rectangular array of numbers — rows first, columns second (RC rule). Each entry is denoted $a_{ij}$ (row $i$, column $j$). Matrix addition and subtraction are only defined when both matrices have identical dimensions — then you operate entry by entry. Addition is commutative ($A + B = B + A$); subtraction is not ($A - B \neq B - A$). Scalar multiplication multiplies every single entry by the scalar $k$ with no exceptions and no dimension check required. For combined expressions like $2A - 3B + C$, compute all scalar products first then add and subtract. Matrix equations are solved like regular algebraic equations — add, subtract, or scale both sides — with every operation applied entry by entry. The zero matrix $O$ is the additive identity ($A + O = A$), and $-A$ is the additive inverse ($A + (-A) = O$). These foundations lead directly to matrix multiplication in Section 14.2.
